subject: RE: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
msgSnippet: Eugene, I agree that Iterator isn t the right interface. AbstractCollection or AbstractList would be better. They would allow you to count the elements without
messageBody:
Eugene,

I agree that Iterator isn't the right interface. AbstractCollection or
AbstractList would be better. They would allow you to count the elements
without iterating through them and (as you say) AbstractList would all you
random access to parameters.

I'm not concerned with named sets of parameters yet. I'd like to collect
more concrete experience with parameterized tests before making them more
complicated. My attitude is that they are an experimental feature for the
moment.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Eugene Kuleshov
> Sent: Monday, October 03, 2005 9:15 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Proposed parameterized test syntax for JUnit 4
>
> >It might be better for the @Parameters method to return an
> >Iterator, allowing the lazy creation of substantial data structures,
> >however.
> > @Parameters static Iterator<Object[]> data() ...
> >
> >
> Iterator won't allow to jump directly to the specific test.
> It would
> be useful for IDE runners if user would like to restart only specific
> test case (this scenario us currently not supported in
> Eclipse's JUnit
> runner).

Agreed. AbstractCollection or AbstractList might be better.

>
> >> Second limitation is that user don't have will have to
> >>declaratively
> >>specify test data sets without writing custom @Parameters
> >>method and use
> >>some system property to differentiate between tests. Perhaps
> >>you can add
> >>some "name" property to Parameters annotation, so test runner
> >>can match
> >>this name with declared test data. Such name property would
> >>also allow
> >>to have multiple @Parameters methods and match them with
> >>@Test methods
> >>if you'll have same name there too. The last would allow to
> >>have several
> >>test methods with different kinds of test parameters
> without creating
> >>separate test classes (so you'll have single test class for
> >>class under
> >>testing).
> >>
> >>
> >I don't understand this objection. Can you write an example
> of what you
> >would like to see?
> >
> >
> Ok. I may have several data sets (e.g. small one for smoke
> testing and
> a really huge one for complete regression testing) and I want
> to choose
> between them from the runner. For instance:
>
> @Parameters(name="smoke") public static Object[] data() {
> return new int[][] {{0, 0}, {1, 1}};
> }
>
> @Parameters(name="full") public static Object[] data() {
> // load data from external file or generate permutations
> return data;
> }
>
> Then you'll specify test type "smoke" or "full" on a runner and it
> will choose an appropriate set of the test data.
>
> >> The last thing I'd like to mention is that current
> >>@Parameters methods
> >>won't scale to large data sets (the same limitation also exists in
> >>TestNG). I've seen JUnit3 suite() methods that produced
> thousands of
> >>test permutations and that required lots of memory memory
> >>when running
> >>tests. So, It think that it would make sense to introduce an
> >>interface
> >>similar to JDBC ResultSet, so test runner can create iterate
> >>trough test
> >>data without loading it completely into memory and also have
> >>option to
> >>get number of tests as well as jump to Nth test. You can also
> >>provide an
> >>adapter that will take Object[][] and provide all that
> >>functionality for
> >>users who don't want to create test data dynamically.
> >>
> >>
> >Would the Iterator version satisfy the need to handle large
> data sets?
> >
> >
> The limitation of the iterator is that it does not provide a random
> access. This would make difficult to rerun only selected test
> case (e.g.
> failed one)
>
> regards,
> Eugene
